unnormalised: New Delhi: India observes Republic Day annually on Jan 26th. This date marks the adoption of the Constitution of India, succeeding the Government of India Act 1935 as the governing document of the nation. The Constitution, a landmark achievement, was adopted by the Indian Constituent Assembly on 26/11/1949. However, it officially came into effect on 26/01/1950.
normalised: New Delhi: India observes Republic Day annually on january twenty sixth. This date marks the adoption of the Constitution of India, succeeding the Government of India Act one thousand nine hundred and thirty five as the governing document of the nation. The Constitution, a landmark achievement, was adopted by the Indian Constituent Assembly on twenty sixth november one thousand nine hundred and forty nine. However, it officially came into effect on twenty sixth january one thousand nine hundred and fifty.

unnormalised: This historical date, 26 Jan, was deliberately chosen because it commemorates the Purna Swaraj declaration of 1930. On this day in 1930, the Indian National Congress proclaimed India's resolution for complete independence from British rule. This declaration took place on the banks of the Ravi river. It preponed the earlier goal of dominion status.
normalised: This historical date, twenty sixth january, was deliberately chosen because it commemorates the Purna Swaraj declaration of one thousand nine hundred and thirty. On this day in one thousand nine hundred and thirty, the Indian National Congress proclaimed India's resolution for complete independence from British rule. This declaration took place on the banks of the Ravi river. It preponed the earlier goal of dominion status.

unnormalised: Every year, Republic Day celebrations include a grand parade in New Delhi. This parade often showcases India's military strength, cultural diversity, and technological advancements. The President of India typically hoists the national flag. It's a day to remember the sacrifices made for the nation's freedom and to reflect on the values enshrined in the Constitution.
